awd_titl_txt: Phase II I/UCRC U. of Alabama at Birmingham Site: Center for Health Organization Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
Phase II I/UCRC U. of Alabama at Birmingham Site: Center for Health Organization Transformation

Partnerships between university and industry can result in innovative solutions to the complex issues affecting the U.S. health care system. The University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) site of the Center for Health Organization Transformation (CHOT) represents a collaboration between UAB and industry partners to engage in applied industry research to provide evidence on innovations that can improve health care quality and access, while reducing costs.  Industry partners include a broad spectrum of health-related organizations (health systems, hospital, home health, rehabilitation) serving Alabama, Louisiana, and other states. The UAB/CHOT affiliation will facilitate and accelerate such research by our joining an experienced learning collaborative, and by leveraging the resources of UAB and its industry partners. Our projects have implications for the prevention of health conditions that disproportionately affect racial/ethnic minorities, particularly in the Deep South, such as diabetes, obesity, avoidable readmissions, and falls. 

The UAB CHOT site?s mission/vision is "to generate knowledge with respect to health care delivery innovations that may result in efficient, high-quality care that is patient-centered and equitable through collaborative research with industry." The UAB CHOT site's research focus includes organizational processes and the evaluation of health care delivery innovations, health information technology, quality improvement, and patient experience including care coordination. UAB will expand CHOT's existing research capacity, increase its geographic presence in the Deep South, and broaden industry partner types involved in changing the U.S. health delivery system. UAB's participation in the CHOT will enhance our diverse students' experience in the classroom and in the field, and provide faculty with opportunities for practice-based, multi-disciplinary research. Finally, the broader scientific community will benefit through the dissemination of our projects' findings through refereed publications, presentations at scientific meetings and CHOT sponsored communication venues - webinars, and newsletters.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The University of Alabama at Birmingham?s (UAB) goal as a university member site of the Center of Health Organization Transformation (CHOT) academic/industry learning collaborative was to engage in practice-based research focusing on the evaluation of health care delivery innovations, health information technology, quality improvement, and patient experience including care coordination. We utilized a multi-disciplinary approach to generate knowledge with respect to health care delivery innovations that may result in efficient, high-quality care that is patient-centered and equitable through collaborate research with industry. The UAB site worked closely with other CHOT academic member sites as well as the various healthcare industry partners regarding the submission and selection of research projects, monitoring their progress as well as the dissemination of findings. Working in this collaborative academic/industry manner, initiatives were developed at various levels, such as (1) sharing of researchers' expertise, (2) replicating prior CHOT studies with another site's industry partner, and/or (3) engaging two or more academic sites and industry partners in the same research project (i.e., continuum or transition of care project with hospital, home health and physician group using technology). The UAB CHOT related projects have and continue to contribute to the knowledge base of technology and organizational science applications to improve access to care and care coordination in health care. Over the years, we have presented our research findings through peer-reviewed publications and national conferences. In addition, UAB CHOT projects have potential to serve as pilot projects that can be leveraged to secure extramural funding for larger scale projects. For example, one of our 2018-2019 projects, in collaboration with the National Center on Health, Physical Activity and Disability, informed the development of the strategic plan for developing wellness programs mobility limitations which was funded by the Center of Disease Control. Finally, the UAB CHOT site activities have provided students (undergraduate, master?s and doctoral) the opportunities to learn about industry/university collaborative research. These experiences provided the students unique opportunities to participate in experiential learning of health services research methods and to observe firsthand the issues and challenges faced by industry members and health system partners in the dynamic changing health care landscape.


Last Modified: 10/25/2021
Modified by: Robert Weech-Maldonado
